# Enumeration with [[Nmap]]
```shell
becker63@htb[/htb]$ sudo nmap --script nfs* 10.129.14.128 -sV -p111,2049

Starting Nmap 7.80 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2021-09-19 17:37 CEST
Nmap scan report for 10.129.14.128
Host is up (0.00021s latency).

PORT     STATE SERVICE VERSION
111/tcp  open  rpcbind 2-4 (RPC #100000)
| nfs-ls: Volume /mnt/nfs
|   access: Read Lookup NoModify NoExtend NoDelete NoExecute
| PERMISSION  UID    GID    SIZE  TIME                 FILENAME
| rwxrwxrwx   65534  65534  4096  2021-09-19T15:28:17  .
| ??????????  ?      ?      ?     ?                    ..
| rw-r--r--   0      0      1872  2021-09-19T15:27:42  id_rsa
| rw-r--r--   0      0      348   2021-09-19T15:28:17  id_rsa.pub
| rw-r--r--   0      0      0     2021-09-19T15:22:30  nfs.share
|_
| nfs-showmount: 
|_  /mnt/nfs 10.129.14.0/24
| nfs-statfs: 
|   Filesystem  1K-blocks   Used       Available   Use%  Maxfilesize  Maxlink
|_  /mnt/nfs    30313412.0  8074868.0  20675664.0  29%   16.0T        32000
| rpcinfo: 
|   program version    port/proto  service
|   100000  2,3,4        111/tcp   rpcbind
|   100000  2,3,4        111/udp   rpcbind
|   100000  3,4          111/tcp6  rpcbind
|   100000  3,4          111/udp6  rpcbind
|   100003  3           2049/udp   nfs
|   100003  3           2049/udp6  nfs
|   100003  3,4         2049/tcp   nfs
|   100003  3,4         2049/tcp6  nfs
|   100005  1,2,3      41982/udp6  mountd
|   100005  1,2,3      45837/tcp   mountd
|   100005  1,2,3      47217/tcp6  mountd
|   100005  1,2,3      58830/udp   mountd
|   100021  1,3,4      39542/udp   nlockmgr
|   100021  1,3,4      44629/tcp   nlockmgr
|   100021  1,3,4      45273/tcp6  nlockmgr
|   100021  1,3,4      47524/udp6  nlockmgr
|   100227  3           2049/tcp   nfs_acl
|   100227  3           2049/tcp6  nfs_acl
|   100227  3           2049/udp   nfs_acl
|_  100227  3           2049/udp6  nfs_acl
2049/tcp open  nfs_acl 3 (RPC #100227)
MAC Address: 00:00:00:00:00:00 (VMware)

Service detection performed. Please report any incorrect results at https://nmap.org/submit/ .
Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 0.45 seconds
```

## Nmap scripts
* nfs-ls 
	* List NFS exports and check permissions
* nfs-showmount #
	* Like showmount -e
* nfs-statfs 
	* Disk statistics and info from NFS share

## Metasploit modules 
* scanner/nfs/nfsmount 
	* Scan NFS mounts and list permissions

# NSFShell
```embed
title: "Using nfsshell to compromise older environments | Pen Test Partners"
image: "https://www.pentestpartners.com/content/uploads/2014/10/nfspwn.png"
description: "Today I’m going to explore and demonstrate an old tool called nfsshell and tell you why it’s still pretty killer in some testing situations. Nfsshell is one of those incredibly useful but little known tools. Part of the reason for this is that the Network File System (NFS) is quite rare these days. Not many"
url: "https://www.pentestpartners.com/security-blog/using-nfsshell-to-compromise-older-environments/"
```
CLI tool that lets you do things like spoof your UID so you can access files on the remote system that might be access protected byt that 

*"I’ve created an NFS share on an Ubuntu virtual machine to demonstrate all of the above.*

*First of all, we start up nfsshell, specify the target host, list the exported shares, and finally mount it:*

*![nfsshell8](https://www.pentestpartners.com/content/uploads/2014/10/nfsshell8.jpg)*

*Next, we list what is on the share:*

*![nfsshell9](https://www.pentestpartners.com/content/uploads/2014/10/nfsshell9.jpg)*

*The “FOO” directory looks interesting (bear with me here…):*

*![nfsshell10](https://www.pentestpartners.com/content/uploads/2014/10/nfsshell10.jpg)*

*We can see that the directory is owned by a user with UID and GID equal to 1000, so we set our local UID and GID to be the same:*

*nfs> uid 1000*  
*nfs> gid 1000*

*Let’s try accessing FOO again:*

*![nfsshell11](https://www.pentestpartners.com/content/uploads/2014/10/nfsshell11.jpg)*

*There, we now have access to that test file.*  
*It’s a simple tool but it can be very useful for accessing files on NFS shares without having to create multiple users with different UID and GID combinations."*
